At that time, the World-Honored One addressed King Prasenajit in the great assembly, saying:
Great King!
I will now briefly explain a parable for the king about the faults of being attached to the flavors of birth and death. Listen carefully now!
Think about it well!

In the past, countless eons ago, there was a man who was wandering in the wilderness. He was chased by a ferocious elephant. Terrified, he ran without support. He saw a well with empty water nearby, with tree roots. He immediately went down along the roots and hid in the well.
There were two rats, one black and one white, gnawing at the tree roots.
On the four sides of the well, there were four poisonous snakes wanting to bite the man;
below, there was a poisonous dragon.
He was afraid of the dragon and snakes, fearing that the tree roots would break.
The honey at the tree's root, with five drops falling into his mouth, the tree shook and the bees scattered, stinging the man below. A wild fire then came and burned the tree.
The king said:
How could this man, experiencing immeasurable suffering, crave those few drops of honey?
At that time the World-Honored One said:
Great King!

The wilderness is a metaphor for the long night of ignorance. The man is a metaphor for ordinary beings. The elephant is a metaphor for impermanence. The well is a metaphor for birth and death. The tree root on the steep cliff is a metaphor for life. The two rats, black and white, are metaphors for day and night. Their gnawing at the tree root is a metaphor for moment-to-moment cessation. The four poisonous snakes are metaphors for the four elements. The honey is a metaphor for the five desires. The bees are metaphors for deviant thoughts. The fire is a metaphor for old age and sickness. The poisonous dragon is a metaphor for death.
Therefore, Great King!
You should know that birth, old age, sickness, and death are extremely frightening. You should always contemplate them and not be swallowed by the five desires.
At that time the World-Honored One spoke a verse again:
In the wilderness, on a path of ignorance, a running person is likened to an ordinary person,
A great elephant is compared to impermanence, a well is likened to the shore of birth and death;
The tree's roots are likened to life, the two rats are the same in day and night,
Chewing on the roots, decaying moment by moment, the four snakes are the same as the four great elements;
A drop of honey is likened to the five desires, a bee sting is compared to wrong thoughts,
Fire is the same as old age and sickness, a poisonous dragon is equivalent to the suffering of death.
A wise person observes these things, the elephant can be disgusted with the flow of birth,
Without attachment to the five desires in the mind, only then is one called a liberated person.
Dwelling in the ocean of ignorance, always driven by the king of death,
How can one know to cling to sound and color, not enjoying leaving the ordinary person?

At that time, King Prasenajit, hearing the Buddha explain the faults of birth and death, attained what he had never had before, deeply giving rise to disgust and detachment, joining palms in respect, single-mindedly gazing up, and said to the Buddha:
World-Honored One!
The TathÄgata's great compassion explains such subtle and wonderful Dharma meanings. I now accept them on the crown of my head.
The Buddha said:
Excellent, excellent!
Great King!
You should practice as taught, and do not be negligent.
At that time, King Prasenajit and the great assembly were all delighted, and with faith and acceptance, they practiced accordingly.
